label: axiom-bounded-measurement-variance
name: Axiom of Bounded Measurement Variance
core_assumption: The variance of the raw value measurement process, summed over all N walkers, must be uniformly bounded across all possible swarm states. This axiom prevents the stochastic noise inherent in measurement from having pathologically heavy tails that would make the expectation of the squared error diverge. It is a foundational requirement for proving that stochastic measurement operators satisfy mean-square continuity. By bounding the total variance uniformly, this axiom isolates stochastic fluctuations as a controlled, finite contribution to the total expected squared error, allowing the analytical challenge to focus on bounding the change in the mean of the measurement operator. This axiom applies to any Raw Value Operator V: Σ_N → P(ℝ^N) that is used in the algorithm's measurement pipeline.

parameters.name: Maximum Measurement Variance
parameters.description: A constant that provides a uniform upper bound on the expected squared deviation of a sampled raw value vector from its mean, summed over all N walkers. This parameter quantifies the maximum total stochastic noise that the measurement process can introduce, regardless of the swarm configuration.
parameters.canonical_bounds: For Distance-to-Companion Measurement: κ²_variance = N · D_Y², where D_Y is the diameter of the algorithmic space (proven in Theorem thm-distance-operator-satisfies-bounded-variance-axiom)

parameters.name: Swarm State
parameters.description: Any swarm configuration in the N-particle state space Σ_N. The axiom requires the variance bound to hold uniformly for all possible swarm states, ensuring that stochastic noise remains controlled regardless of the swarm's spatial configuration or survival status distribution.

parameters.name: Sampled Raw Value Vector
parameters.description: An N-dimensional real-valued vector sampled from the probability distribution V(S). For any walker i in the alive set A(S), v_i is the raw measurement value for that walker. For dead walkers (i ∉ A(S)), v_i is deterministically zero. This is the stochastic quantity whose variance the axiom constrains.

parameters.name: Expectation of Raw Value Vector
parameters.description: The expected value of the sampled raw value vector under the measurement distribution V(S). This is the mean vector with respect to which the variance is computed. For deterministic operators (e.g., reward measurement), E[v] = v. For stochastic operators (e.g., distance-to-companion), E[v] is the vector of expected distances.

parameters.name: Raw Value Operator
parameters.description: A function that maps a swarm state S ∈ Σ_N to a probability distribution over N-dimensional real-valued vectors. This abstract operator encapsulates any measurement process used in the algorithm's pipeline, including deterministic measurements (reward) and stochastic measurements (distance-to-companion). The axiom constrains the variance properties that any valid V must satisfy.

parameters.name: Swarm Size
parameters.description: The total number of walkers in the swarm. The variance bound applies to the sum over all N components of the raw value vector. Larger N typically leads to larger κ²_variance for distance-based measurements, as there are more independent stochastic contributions.

condition: For any swarm state S ∈ Σ_N, let v ~ V(S) be a sampled raw value vector and let E[v] be its expectation under the measurement distribution V(S). The Raw Value Operator V must satisfy: E[‖v - E[v]‖₂²] ≤ κ²_variance. This condition must hold uniformly for all swarm states, meaning that κ²_variance is a global constant independent of S. The user of the framework is responsible for proving that their chosen Raw Value Operator satisfies this axiom by explicitly computing or bounding κ²_variance.

failure_mode_analysis.primary_failure: Unbounded Variance and Divergent Expected Error
failure_mode_analysis.mechanism: If this axiom is violated, the raw measurement process can have unbounded variance. This allows for rare but arbitrarily large measurement errors (heavy-tailed noise distributions), causing the expected squared error E[‖v₁ - v₂‖²] to be infinite. The stochastic component of the error decomposition becomes uncontrollable.

consequences.effect: The measurement operator produces samples that can deviate arbitrarily far from their mean with non-negligible probability. Heavy-tailed distributions (e.g., Cauchy, infinite-variance distributions) cause the second moment to diverge.
consequences.downstream_impact: Mean-square continuity of the Raw Value Operator (Axiom axiom-raw-value-mean-square-continuity) cannot be established. The bounding function F_V,ms(S₁,S₂) diverges, making it impossible to prove continuity of the standardization pipeline and cloning operator. The entire stability analysis breaks down.

consequences.effect: Even if κ²_variance is finite for some states, it may grow unboundedly for other swarm configurations (e.g., near singularities or when the swarm approaches special regions). The uniform bound requirement is violated.
consequences.downstream_impact: The operator's continuity properties are non-uniform across the state space. Certain swarm configurations become 'pathological,' causing instability when the swarm enters those regions. Algorithm behavior becomes unpredictable and non-robust.

consequences.effect: If the measurement process has strong positive correlations between walker measurements (not adequately accounted for), the total variance can grow faster than linearly with N, potentially exceeding the bound.
consequences.downstream_impact: The scaling of κ²_variance with system size N becomes unfavorable. For distance-based measurements, κ²_variance ~ N·D_Y² is already linear in N; further amplification would degrade scalability.

diagnostic_protocol: Empirically measure the sample variance E[‖v - E[v]‖²] across diverse swarm configurations
Check for heavy-tailed behavior by analyzing the distribution of ‖v - E[v]‖² (outliers, tail decay)
Verify that variance is uniformly bounded across all regions of the state space (no singularities)
For stochastic operators, ensure independence or bounded correlation between walker measurements
Compute theoretical upper bounds based on the measurement mechanism (e.g., bounded support → bounded variance)

mitigation_strategies.rationale: If individual measurements v_i are bounded (e.g., v_i ∈ [0, D_Y] for distances), the variance is automatically bounded: Var(v_i) ≤ E[v_i²] ≤ D_Y². Summing over N walkers gives κ²_variance ≤ N·D_Y².
mitigation_strategies.tradeoff: None - this is the canonical approach for distance-based measurements

mitigation_strategies.rationale: If the natural measurement distribution has heavy tails, apply truncation at a high quantile or use a regularized version (e.g., replace Cauchy with Student's t with finite variance).
mitigation_strategies.tradeoff: May introduce bias if truncation is too aggressive; changes the measurement semantics

mitigation_strategies.rationale: Ensure that the measurement process for different walkers introduces independent noise. If correlations are unavoidable, explicitly account for them in the variance bound calculation.
mitigation_strategies.tradeoff: May require redesigning measurement protocols; not always feasible for inherently correlated measurements

mitigation_strategies.rationale: For each Raw Value Operator, prove mathematically that E[v_i²] < ∞ for all alive walkers. This guarantees finite variance by construction.
mitigation_strategies.tradeoff: Requires rigorous analysis; may reveal fundamental limitations of certain measurement designs

failure_mode_analysis.critical_threshold: For the Distance-to-Companion Measurement operator, κ²_variance = N·D_Y² is the canonical bound (Theorem thm-distance-operator-satisfies-bounded-variance-axiom). Any operator with κ²_variance >> N·D_Y² should be carefully scrutinized for potential variance explosion issues.
failure_mode_analysis.system_level_impact: This axiom is a critical ingredient in proving mean-square continuity for stochastic Raw Value Operators. It appears explicitly in the error decomposition: E[‖v₁ - v₂‖²] ≤ 3·κ²_variance + 3·‖E[v₁] - E[v₂]‖² + 3·κ²_variance (Theorem thm-distance-operator-mean-square-continuity, Section 10.3.3). Without this bound, the standardization pipeline's continuity proofs fail, and the entire algorithm's stability guarantees collapse. This axiom gates the validity of the framework for any stochastic measurement process.
